title: Visualizing Lecture Capture Usage

author: Christopher Brooks, Department of Computer Science, University of Saskatchewan

segmentation: OK so I'm I'm Chris Brooks from the University of Saskatchewan and Stephanie said some things earlier about this being a workshop, and I think that this is really important to note that this is early work that we've been working on.

We deal with lecture capture I've been working with lecture capture for a number of years as well as my colleagues Crag and Jim, and this work is focusing on how do we do a visual analysis of lecture capture data to better understand our students to better understand our teaching and to better understand course dynamics?
And I'm going to give a couple of examples of that.

My previous work is actually in statistical models to do that as well, and so there's something statistical models sometimes can tell you very nicely, and some things that they can't tell you very nicely, and so I'm interested in when we use different toolkits within learning analytics to do different things.
So when do we use HCI methods?
When do we use AI methods?
When do we use methods from social Sciences and so forth?
Alright, so this is the environment that we're working in.
It's called recollect.
It was built in house for lecture.
Capture is very similar to many other systems.
Mediasite Echo 360, opencast Matterhorn etc etc.
So the deal is instructor walks into the class, starts talking a cameras point in the corners pointed at them.
It automatically captures them.
It publishes the video.
There's no editing of video.
It's a very authentic recording of what happens in the classroom.
As opposed to these prepared media snippets that are maybe high quality, high production values, etc.
We use we don't even use cameras this nice.
We use security cameras often because the focus is not on creating a high high production necessarily, but in scaling it out throughout the institution so that every classroom can have it.
This is another example of the same system you can see at the bottom.
It's probably tough to see, but we have some notetaking opportunities as well.
For students, every button, every slider, every text box is embellished with data tracking as well as we get 30 second heartbeats, and those are the ones I'm going to be talking about the most.
So what this is is when a student logs in every 30 seconds, we get an update.
Is the video playing?
Is it in a pause state?
Where are they in the video?
What is there, you know all the IP, thumbprint, information as well?
What's the volume level, etc.
We also get events whenever they change the volume whenever they navigate to something they can actually hover over these little indicies on the left and see a blown up picture.
We get events when those pop up when those pop down.
So it's very finely grained data that we get.
I should note that I'm involved in the opencast Matterhorn lecture capture project.
It's an open source, free, wonderful, enterprise ready.
System is very collaborative led by UC Berkeley, an 8 hours there Zurich and it's used in dozens of institutions.
So if you're looking to do some lecture capture and you're just getting into that, and you want to talk to me about opencast, I would love to talk to you about that too.
Alright, so there's we had three different interests and I'm going to kind of ripped through them here quickly.
But the first interest we were motivated by a correlative link between rereading discussion form messages and academic performance.
So what we had found previously or what a previous student had found was that people who re read postings tend to do better on exams and so that was interesting to us.
Is this the same thing with people who re watch lecture video and what's it mean then to rewatch Electro video you have to watch the whole lecture video.
Do you have to watch pieces of it?
Etc so we started to wonder how different students review content and how this may benefit us understanding what their learning style.
Look like, so, here's here's here's an example of a visualization that we did for this each.
So this is a single student Anna single video.

The time in the video is all along the left and the playback duration is on the right, so a complete diagonal line means I started at the beginning and I watched it all the way through and as that diagonal line kind of moves down as as the slope lessons, it means I was pausing or I slowed the video or so forth.
So this was one example.
So and so colors are different sessions, so this is rewatching behavior.
I'm only showing students who watched it multiple times, so blue is one day, red is another day, yellow is another day, and so forth, and the full figures in the paper, if you're interested.
So this was an example of what we called the regular watcher.
They would sit there.
Lots of strong diagonal lines, the horizontal lines they just hit pause and went off to the bathroom, or something like that.
And not not a lot of pausing though they sat there and they re watched the whole lecture verbatim.
This is what we call the engaged rewater an these labels are something that we just made as we were trying to understand the data set a little bit better.
But we can see here, especially that there's a little jaggedness to the line and the slope is actually quite small.
This is a student who's watching them pausing, going back a little bit, watching again, pausing, watching, pausing, maybe making notes.
Maybe they're working on an assignment that has something to do with what was being discussed in class and so forth, so we're trying to tie what we believe pedagogically.
Is happening here to the patterns of their use and you can see that up here.
It's maybe very faint.
There's a green line and there's a yellow line, and they're very similar.

This student watched the same chunk of video twice, so this is kind of a full re watching of this segment of video and that's really interesting because it it suggested that might be very important, and at least it was important for this student.
Now, of course, error bounds in any of these systems.
The student could have been playing the video with a bad Internet connection and just going to the washroom.
And that might have created a similar line without learning happening, but it's a start towards visual analytic.
And then here we call this the pazari watcher, and what blew my mind when we first started looking at the data for for this is how many students use pause.
And in fact the load 3 videos at once in different tabs, pause them all and come back a day later and start watching it.
I had no idea that this is how students use this, but this was a very common pattern.
So here we see somebody who's watching pauses for 10 minute breaks, watching pauses, watching pauses, watching pauses.
So one of the things that we don't have in our environment right now is high speed playback.

To throw in here.

The second investigation we were interested in was temporal viewership.
We wanted to see how learners use a system throughout the term.

So the question that came up is, do students just watch the newest lecture?
Are they watching old content to what does it mean to be watching regularly every week?

What was interesting to me and I don't know this might be a little faint is that there's kind of another line here.
